target_text: "It is important to also assure internal quality. Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Doctoral Researcher; Discipline: Information Systems (QS); Research: Human-Centered Computing & Software Engineering (NSF); Biases: process-centric, socio-technical, internal validity emphasis

codebook.justification: [It is important to also assure internal quality.] From an IS/HCC doctoral stance, this signals a normative emphasis on internal validity and process-centric assurance.
[the way that the system has been built and designed.] As a CS/IS qualitative analyst, I read this as design-oriented criteria privileging architecture and rationale over outcomes.
[Internal quality] depends on [the way that the system has been built and designed.]. I assume socio-technical process integrity—coding for craft rigor and traceable engineering practices.
As a PhD candidate in software engineering, I read [assure internal quality] as foregrounding process and code-level attributes, judgment-laden socio-technical quality criteria.
Referencing [the system has been built and designed] invokes architectural integrity and maintainability, norms I privilege methodologically; their assessment is inherently interpretive.
Framing quality as [Internal quality] centers development practices and design rationale; my bias favors internal metrics as proxies for reliability and trustworthiness.
Stating it is [important to also assure internal quality] signals a risk posture elevating assurance activities, an evaluative prioritization shaped by discipline-specific values.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Researcher—Doctoral; CS & Information Systems; NSF: Human-Centered Computing; Bias: process-quality emphasis

codebook.justification: Reading [assure internal quality] as a normative emphasis signals value-laden prioritization, adjudicated via contested SE metrics (maintainability, testability), not a single ground truth.
The claim [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.] frames quality as lifecycle/process-dependent, weighted differently across methodologies.
The phrase [built and designed] invokes judgments about cohesion, coupling, and design integrity—interpretive, context-specific criteria rather than objective facts.

Agreed.definition: The text prioritizes ensuring internal quality: [It is important to also assure internal quality.].
Internal quality is defined by system design/build choices: [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].
Internal quality depends on the development process (the way the system was made), not just outcomes: [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].

Disagreed.definition: Diverges by emphasizing a risk/assurance posture (the priority of assurance) rather than characterizing what internal quality consists of; grounded in [It is important to also assure internal quality.].
Narrows internal quality to architecture-level properties (e.g., cohesion/coupling), a more specific criterion than the text states; motivated by [built and designed].

Infers socio-technical integrity and traceability of the build process beyond the text’s general linkage of quality to how the system was made; grounded in [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].

disagree_explain:
Software Quality Researcher: ‘Assurance Priority’ reads [It is important to also assure internal quality.] as a risk/assurance posture, not a definition of internal quality. Reflective Researcher—Doctoral: ‘Architectural Soundness’ over-specifies internal quality to architecture beyond [built and designed]. Reflective Doctoral Researcher: ‘Build Process Integrity’ infers socio-technical traceability beyond the general link in [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].
Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion

Closing.definition: All roles support retaining the code. The text clearly separates an assurance posture (It is important to also assure internal quality) from a definitional statement, so a distinct code preserves precision, prevents conflation, and supports consistent, efficient annotation.

All roles agree the text frames internal quality broadly—about how a system is built and designed—so equating it solely with architectural properties over-narrows the scope. Retaining the 'Architectural Soundness' disagreement code flags such narrowing and preserves annotation fidelity and consistency.

The passage defines internal quality solely as how the system was built and designed and stresses assuring it, without mentioning process integrity, socio-technical concerns, or traceability. Because the proposed code imports unstated constructs, it lacks textual grounding and would risk inconsistent, over-broad annotation.

Codebook.definition: The text prioritizes ensuring internal quality: [It is important to also assure internal quality.].
Internal quality is defined by system design/build choices: [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].
Internal quality depends on the development process (the way the system was made), not just outcomes: [Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.].

Codebook.*definition: All roles support retaining the code. The text clearly separates an assurance posture (It is important to also assure internal quality) from a definitional statement, so a distinct code preserves precision, prevents conflation, and supports consistent, efficient annotation.

Retaining the 'Architectural Soundness' disagreement code flags such narrowing and preserves annotation fidelity and consistency.
